turns.content: Aluminium grinding dust. ATEX Zone 22. GDB housing in FZ.

For the aluminium grinding dust application in ATEX Zone 22, we'll configure a GDB housing. The presence of an Explosive Atmosphere means all components must be grounded to prevent ignition sources from static discharge. The housing itself has corrosion class C2.The metalworking application also exposes the system to Particulate Exposure, requiring mechanical filtration.To finalize the configuration, I need two details:

content_segments.text: For the metalworking application, we're configuring a GDB filter housing with 300x600mm dimensions and PG connection type, suitable for an airflow of 1000 mÂ³/h. The housing material is FZ (C3 corrosion class), and it will be installed indoors.
This application exposes the system to Particulate Exposure. To ensure effective filtration, a mechanical filter is required.

The system will also be installed in an Explosive Atmosphere (ATEX Zone 22). In such environments, static discharge from non-grounded components can create sparks, which is a significant ignition risk. Therefore, all metallic components of the housing must be grounded to prevent static discharge.

turns.content: This GDB housing configuration is designed for your metalworking application.The system will be exposed to Particulate Exposure from grinding and welding. Since your application also involves an Explosive Atmosphere (ATEX Zone 22), all components must be electrostatically grounded to prevent spark ignition. Static charge on ungrounded filter housings can produce sparks exceeding the minimum ignition energy of many dust/gas mixtures.The housing corrosion class is C2.Tag item_1**Note**: Explosive atmosphere (ATEX zone) requires all components to be electrostatically grounded to prevent spark ignition. Consider products with this trait**Note**: Explosive atmospheres require all components to prevent ignition sources. Static charge on ungrounded filter housings can produce sparks exceeding the minimum ignition energy of many dust/gas mixtures. MANDATORY REQUIREMENTS: (1) Grounding/earthing of all metallic housing components to prevent static discharge; (2) Anti-static filter media with conductive fibers or grounding strips â€” standard filter media is NOT suitable for ATEX zones; (3) Equipotential bonding between all housing sections; (4) Compliance with EN 60079-0 (general requirements) and EN 60079-31 (dust ignition protection). For Zone 22 (combustible dust): equipment must meet minimum Category 3D protection level. Non-negotiable â€” follow engineering recommendation

However, the system recommends a standard GDB in FZ for an ATEX Zone 22 aluminium dust application without confirming the housing itself is ATEX-certified/Category 3D and without addressing key dust-explosion design needs (explosion isolation/venting, fan/motor compliance), making the recommendation unsafe and constraint-violating for many real installations.
